hobby.message: Typewriters treating you better than people?
Political literature still keeping you up?
Any new mods on your FPV quad?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: No, made it here without incident. Quiet for my part of town.
You know, I restore old typewriters—keeps my hands busy.
Sometimes the outages get in the way, but nothing unbearable.
Best to keep such things low-profile lately.
No trouble, just the usual interruptions along the way.
Been keeping up with my hobby—restoring typewriters.
Hard to get supplies; deliveries have become unpredictable.
Noisy neighbors complicate things, not that it matters.
Old machines still work, even without power.
No problem, just some street commotion—people shuffling parcels again.
Spent the afternoon with my Olivetti, cleaning the typebars.
Restoring typewriters is how I pass the time—beats staring at screens.
Supply shortages make finding ribbons and parts tougher lately.
With the blackouts, manual machines are dependable.
Noise from downstairs nearly made me ruin a spring.
Getting here was fine, if you don't count the protests.
Actually, I lost an hour fixing a jammed key on my Remington.
I restore antique typewriters—it's a stubborn old habit.
Worked through a blackout, just lantern and ink-stained fingers.
Parcels rarely arrive; had to improvise with ribbon this week.
Funny how people fight over water credits, but ignore real history.
Sometimes, I write a line or two, just for myself.
No trouble. My route's familiar—old habits linger even as the city shifts.
Spent this morning oiling an Olympia frame, listening to the neighborhood assemblies on the stairs.
I restore and collect typewriters—machines from before all this compliance business.
Lately, power cuts make it more necessary; BCI can't see ink and metal.
Harder to find ribbons now—black market or nothing since the Council froze trade.
After the last leak, neighbors got curious about my manual work, thought it was coded.
Funny how, before BCI, people just wrote freely, not fearing audits every keystroke.
Still, putting words to paper feels safer now than any encrypted tablet these days.
hobby_answer: Managed to fix it. Taking care not to leave things out lately.
Lot of eyes and ears these days. Even hobbies draw notice.
After last week’s outages, I keep ink and tools hidden.
Too many people watching who carries what through these blocks.
Not much more to say.
Yes, it’s working, for now.
Strange how blackouts slow even the smallest repairs.
Harder to find new ribbons since the assemblies started blocking market access.
Paper feels safer these days than any screen, given the leaks.
Still, best not to leave typed pages lying around now.
Old habits—paranoia, maybe.
Yes, finally got that S key straightened out, thank you.
Felt good to hear the old click again, even with half the block shouting.
Power cuts made me appreciate non-electric things.
Odd how just writing a note feels private with the system down.
The market’s strange—now you trade food for tools.
I keep my journal brief, stick to tasks, not opinions.
People are jumpy about what gets written and by whom.
It’s working—took me all evening last week to get the carriage aligned.
Amazing what you find during outages—spare screws, forgotten notes stuck behind the platen.
I’m writing more with the city’s networks shaky. Safer now, on paper than on any device.
BCI leaks had neighbors accusing each other. Even a typewriter draws stares.
No one checked what I was carrying until these assemblies replaced old staff.
When things calm, they’ll want history—someone has to leave a record.
Hard to know which stories are safe to tell, though.
Odd comfort, hearing the keys but not the city humming.
It’s working. That Olivetti’s outlasted three office blocks, half the Council, and most networks.
Used to type meeting summaries. Now I document the cracks forming—by hand, quietly.
Recent data leaks... made it dangerous to even leave a note for the cleaner.
Typed lines stay off the net—no BCI trail, not even metadata to misread.
Seems petty, but old ribbons are suddenly a barter item after market controls collapsed.
Had to trade a ration card for WD-40 last week. Just for the carriage.
I write at night, curtains drawn. Hard to avoid paranoia with neighbors on edge.
I’ve hidden pages in the briefcase from my last year—can’t trust open shelves anymore.
Odd, how losing oversight meant watching each other closer than before.
